reviews: Bottle. Caramel, brown sugar, nutty coffee, light resiny hops. Chewy with a balancing bitterness. Excellent.
Cask at GBBF 2007, Earl’s Court on 08/08/2007.  Really liked this; its big on the cereal and malt and also on the piney and…
Tap, brown, toffee, coffee, plum, lots of hops, complex, oily texture, strong

Brown with a creamy, sticky head that lingers. Strong toffee & caramel aroma. Taste is intensely sweet with mild sour undertones. Medium body, mild carbonation, slightly watery texture. Closer to a scotch ale than a bIPA. Interesting but not very likeable.
Just like the other Dogfish Head beers I have had this is one has a strong flavor.  It tastes a lot like a dark beer but then it is an IPA.  It is ok but I am not a huge fan.

Der Typ "Indian Brown Ale" ist schon einmal etwas neues. Es soll auf die Vielseitigkeit des Bieres hingewisen werden und dass von einem Brown Ale und IPA Aromen vorhanden sind. Es dominieren aber natürlich die malzigen Aromen und schaffen eine röstmalzige, karamelliges Basis, welche mit einzielnen Hopfenspitzen gewürzt ist.
Ein interessantes, untypisches Bier, das mich aber nicht vollends überzeugen konnte.

Pours a very dark red color.  Two fingers mocha colored head.  Okay retention, okay lacing.

Yum, smells like a stout.  Dark malt, brown sugar.  Cocoa, coffee.

Taste is stout.  Coffee, cocoa, vanilla, roasty malts. A little more hop than a stout.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied.  Thin.  Watery.

Overall, I initially gave it a very high rating.  But it’s less IPAand more stout.  It’s a pretty good stout, but a bad IPA, but add the fact they call it a brown ale....I’ve given it a lower rating than it deserves.  It’s worth a try, and I would buy it again to investigate further.  It is quite good, but, it’s weird.

Bottle. Single purchased at Super Saver.
Pour was light brown with an off white head. Aroma was nutty, brown sugar, caramel malt, mild roasted coffee. Taste was mild sweet, malty, coffee, nut, chocolate, light pine.

Backlog, bottle in 12-13. Pours a clear brown red color with medium off white head. Smell is raisin bread, malt, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor is a lot of the same but more fruity and sweet comparatively. Body is light to medium for style. Ok

Aroma of roast, sugar, booze. Big flavor of coffee, bitter dark chocolate malt, oats, and bread. Rich mouthfeel, lingering aftertaste, very delicious! Amazing palate. I see this one is categorized in a variety of ways, but of all beers I can compare it to, it seems most similar to Founders Porter, just a bit stronger.

Pours dark brown with ruby tint and a one finger light tan head. Aroma is dried fruit, molasses and some coffee. Taste is raisin and brown sugar, moving to coffee and light roast, with a building hop backbone. Finish is roast and hops. A well done brown ale.
Very nice and interesting. Refreshing and quite malty in all aspects. Cloudy and really brown.
Bottle. This was gets a high score for originality. Medium brown in color with a two finger head. Well balanced but does seem to lean more to the hoppy side. Nice beer.
355ml bottle. Pours rubescent dark brown. Muscovado sugar, figs, damsons, chocolate, cigars, cherry. Medium body. Tasty.

On keg at Small Bar, Bristol. Pours clear dark brown with a tan head. Aroma: toasted malts, mocha, nutty, chocolate. Taste: light sweet & bitter, moderate roast, earthy, chocolate, toffee. Medium bodied, avearge carb, lightly bitter finish

Man this is a damn fine beer. It is perfectly balanced hitting you with what you expect from dark beer lovely malt flavours. While this does not punch you in the face with hops like a lot of IPA’s they are their tying it all together.
12 oz. Not hoppy. Dark pour. Amber finish. Good flavor. Just don't expect it to be hoppy like the ipa name may suggest.
Cola- brown, amber with a medium, tan head and a malty, cola, dark chocolate nose. Malty with medium carbonation, some lacing, and a dry, dark fruit finish. Some warming.

Bottle.

A- Pine, gingerbread, brown sugar, molassess.

A- Dark red brown color, dark liquid, off white head.

T- Pine, malty, bready, molasses, citrus, brown sugar, flan.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, slightly bitter finish.

O- Bottle says Dark IPA, RB says Brown Ale, and description says scotch ale, pale ale hybrid. What the hell is this? So many things going on, I'm not really sure what I was drinking. It was okay. My mouth is confused.
not really a dark ipa, i consider this is a combination of scotch ale and brown ale, not so hoppy, maybe i have a bottle which was bottled over half year. A nice malty beer

3/17/18
With A on St. Patrick’s Day while playing star wars LEGO ok ps2. 

Deep, almost opaque brown with a bit of a tan head. 

Nose is roasty chocolate and coffee malt with a bit of astringent hops. 

Complex taste with lots of  roasty malts and caramel malts balanced by big dose of piney, herbal hops. Chocolate/coffee/caramel sweetness initially that turns to a sharp happiness. Pronounced bitterness from both the malt and the hops. 

Medium feel with lingering hops. 

Overall, this is great! A nice brown ale that almost tastes like a hoppy porter. Very dark tasting with a big hop presence.
Butelka w Carpe Kraft. Porządny Brown Ale, bardzo stylowy, nie zaskakuje niczym ani na plus, ani na minus. Orzechy, toffi, mleczna czekolada, trochę rodzynek.

Bottle. Light brown, pretty clear with frothy, medium and quite solid beige head. Good lacing. Chocolate and malty aromas with some vanilla and resins tones, pretty stron and solid. Medium to full body, very smooth and oily mouthfeel. Light sweet start with chocolate and roasted malts flavors, balanced by light bitter / sour finish. Very nice interpretation of this, pretty boring, style.

Nice good yummy beer. A mans beer. I love dogfish. So crafty. It’s dark but still Bitter and not to Malty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters showing a clear, ruby highlighted, dark brown hue, with a decent layer of tan froth, and dots & dashes of foamy lacing. The nose was toasted, moderately roasted & malty, with mocha, woody, and nutty notes. Medium bodied, with okay carbonation, the taste was similar, contributing moderate roasted & earthy bitterness. Labeled a dark IPA, tasty, but came off more as just an adequately bitter Brown Ale.

I went into Indian Brown Ale expecting a slightly lighter Black IPA. I found it to be much different than what I had originally perceived, though I wasn't disappointed. This ale pours amber-brown. Toasted grain, malt sugar, and forest-y hops. Flavor is far more malty than I anticipated. Toffee, brown sugar, dark succulent fruit, and bittersweet chocolate. The hops certainly make this more bitter than the average Brown Ale but not by much.

As brown beers go, this one isn’t bad, I just have trouble squaring the ipa elements it claims.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

~ Taste ขมกำลังดี ( Medium bitter ) หวานเล็กน้อย ( Slighly sweet ) Balance ดี ( well balance ) after taste กลางๆค่อนไปทางยาวกับความขมที่ทำงานลงตัวเป็นอย่างดีกับความหวาน โดยมีกลิ่น Roasted malt ที่คอยประคองมาตลอดทาง ( Medium to long bitter finish with a hint of roasted malt and brown sugar ) 

~ Overall มีความรู้สึกว่า กลิ่น Roasted malt ดูจะกลบกลิ่น hop ไปเสียเยอะ Charactor ของนำตาลทรายแดงมีมาให้สัมผัสได้ตลอดเวลา Balance ดี ใช้ได้เลยครับ

Nice malty IPA. Lots of nutty flavor with a slight hint of chocolate and maybe a bit of coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Barwa ciemnobrązowa, piany sporo, jest trwała. Na początku nie bardzo, taki wysycony ściągający koźlak z dominującym posmakiem kawowym. Po ogrzaniu robi się bardzo ciekawie - nuty owocowe od chmieli harmonijnie współgrają z dużą słodowością. Do tego fajna „belgijskość” od dodanego cukru. Na koniec przyjemny, także słodowy posmak. Bardzo dobre piwo.
355ml bottle at Onlyou, Jimei. Pours brown with a thin off white head. Aroma of chocolate with malt and caramel. Dry bitter finish.
great head with medium carbonation medium body nice aroma and overall amazing brew

Pours dark brown, smooth and translucent, cream head, spotted lacing. Aroma of roasted barley, chocolate and brown sugar. Tastes medium roast bitter, roasted barley, chocolate, brown sugar, fruity hops come in the after taste, and balance this ale very well. Medium body, soft carbonation, very easy to drink, lot of lingering roasted taste. Very enjoyable.

Bottle at Tap Craft Beer Bar, Robertson Quay, Singapore. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy off white head. The aroma is roasted caramel malt, grassy light fruit hop. The flavour is moderate sweet light bitter with a dry grassy, red berry fruit, nettle, spicy, molasses, woody hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with average to soft carbonation. I'd have preferred a little more carbonation but I guess I'm just a black IPA junkie. Not sure this is a brown Ale tho!!

From Mar 2007

Pours from 12oz bottle a clear deep brown with a small head of foam that doesn't last long and doesn't leave any lacing.

The smell is of roasted malt and some citrus hops.

The taste has huge roasted malt up front that smacks you in the face...just as I remember it. ;^) As I take more sips, there's a more than ample infusion of hop bitterness and some dark fruit notes. Man, this is great stuff! So much roastiness and there's some toffee also hitting my taste buds. And just a little bit of warming in the back of my throat that reminds me to sip and take my time with this gem. What a Brown Ale!

Bottom line: This is a top notch example of the style that is a *must* try.

355ml bottle (Ebrowarium.pl) (5:4:4:2:9=2.4)

Very savoury aroma, soy, but also very sweet. Dark red, persistent small tight beige head. Dead palate, slickish from sugars, carbonation does nothing to lift it. Nasty soapy taste, some savoury soy mushroom and sugar mess. Only plus is that it covers the 7.2% behind the mess, but deep down this is a terrible ale.

Draft in Pittsburgh before the Ed Sheehan show. Pours a dark brown with generous head. Roasted malt, floral hop, brown sugar, caramel. Medium body. Medium light bitter. Nice texture. It's been awhile since I've he this one but it is still good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12floz bottle, no date, $1.75 paid as a single, pint glass. Appears a medium-dark brown with some amber glow at the bottom. Head forms a small layer and retains it character. Firmly a brown ale in the nose, aromas of brown sugar and mild roasted malts noted. A fine American brown, resin, tree bark, pine, and faint cocoa flavors comprise this fullish bodied and fairly hoppy dark ale.
Pours deep cloudy brown with low tan head. Aroma of roasty malt, sugar, citrus. Taste is roasty, mild lingering bitter finish. Light and smooth body with soft carbonation.

I'm sorry, I just dont agree. All the hops they advertise here get lost on this thick syrupy molasses with a bitter rotten walnut finish. No, not for me. It sounded great, tasted awful. Its almost like it wanted to be a stout, but it just wasn't. I made it bout 7-8 sips in before i called it quits n dumped it. I am a broke ass law student and cant afford to throw away top dollar brew... But life's too short to drink beer u just dont like, even if ya really wanted to. Sorry dogfish, I still love you.
12oz bottle. Medium reddish brown with a tan head. Chocolate, raisins, toffee, bread, light roast coffee, grassy hops. Medium body. Fresh, mildly bitter finish. Dee-licious.

12oz bottle. Pours brown with a moderate beige head. Aroma is roast, spice, toffee, chocolate, and a light pine. Taste is similar but with some caramel. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Slick-creamy mouthfeel.

UT090917 backlog. On tap at Beavertown Extravaganza 2017, London. Nose is Chocolate. Dark chocolate, mild coffee. Light to medium sweet, medium to heavy bitter. Long hoppy medium to heavy bitter. Medium body, slick, medium carb. 748516

Keg at Beaverfest. Subtle is how I'd sum this beer up. Less sugar than I expected in aroma, perhaps some burnt sugar. Otherwise malt, coffee and nuts. Light bitter taste whicb grows in strength. Light-medium bodied. Slock with a sticky residue. Abrupt finish. Good but too subtle to have too much impact.

Poured from a bottle. Dark brown in color but you can see through it a bit. Head is on the beige side. Nose is malt and coffee as well as caramel and a bit of booziness. Some lighter notes that are hard to place as well. Taste leans towards brown/scotch ale. Definite coffee and malts as well as brown sugar and raisin. Toward the end there is a crisper hoppiness. Interesting beer. More dominated by the darker notes than expected.

Bottle pours a dark brown with a one finger beige head and thick sticky lacing. Aroma is primarily malt. Taste is very rich, heavy malt with a bunch of underlying flavors. Finishes a touch sour with a delicious aftertaste.

Rich malty. Not as hoppy as IPA. Would definitely try to find this beer again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours amber, brown with a nice 3-finger tan head and an aroma of malt and brown sugar. Tastes viscous upfront and of semi-sweet malt and brown sugar upfront with a mild hop finish. It’s medium to full bodied with minimal to moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Hazy dark brown color With medium creamy light brown mostly lastning head. Aroma is roasted malt With notes of chokolade. Sweet chokolade flavor. Creamy palate.

Bottle. Dark mahogany color. Aroma: dark but not burnt malts, tropical fruits, a little wine and higher alcohols, hops and wood, esters. Taste: malt, coffee, chocolate, biscuit, caramel, fruits, fortified wine, medium hop bitterness.

It was a bit rich for my taste. The flavors were powerful it just packed a heavier punch than I was wanting or expecting. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle with commonmac. Brown with full white head. Strong smell of dark notes. Sugary, malty, full bodied. More malty than hoppy . Rich. Ok to good.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with reddish tint, large spongy off-white head, coffee-forest berries aroma, medium carbonation, bitter roasted malt/coffee taste with a hint of molasses, thin body, long bitter finish. Nice coffee dominated brew,

12-ounce bottle pours clear amber-brown with thin tan head and lacing. Aroma: nuts, smoke, caramelized brown sugar. Flavor: molasses, brown sugar, almonds, pine nuts, sour prunes juice, raisins, chocolate, coffee, ash. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied, dry finish, yet somewhat oily.

Part of a 4 beer flight at TJ Stone , Washington DC in May 2017. Good example of a brown. Heavy on the roast.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle dark auburn color thin off white head aroma is brown sugar and roasted malt taste is the same with a smooth short finish

Originally rated on 12/31/08. The brewers description of this as part scotch ale, IPA, and brown ale is pretty accurate. Aroma of toasted caramel malts, alcohol, and some floral hints. Flavor is the same as aroma with some nuttiness and a coffee finish. A little on the sweet side but its hearty and filling, I liked it.

0,33l bottle from Beergium. Dark brown beer with long lasting light beige head. Aroma has sweet dark malts, some caramel and roastiness. Maybe some hints of coffee also. Taste has sweet malts, hops, some roastiness and coffee. Medium body and medium carbonation. Quite ok.

12oz bottle picked up at The Ale Jail in St. Paul. Consumed in a spiegelau IPA glass. Amber/brown in color with a light tan head. Aroma has traits of hops with toffee, caramel, and an almost cookie like characteristic. Taste has qualities of molasses with toffee and brown sugar. Notes of coffee almost come through which was a little bit unexpected. There is a bitterness present especially at the finish with a residual bit of sugar. Really a strange blend of a lighter coffee stout and a traditional Dogfish Head IPA. Mouthfeel is slightly thin but has some minor oily characteristics. Something a little too unbalanced in this effort for my taste. Pretty decent for a brown ale.

355ml bottle. Clear, dark brown colour with ruby glimmer and small to average, creamy, half-way lasting, moderately lacing, beige head. Spicy aroma of roasted barley, hints of burnt coffee, burnt caramel, a touch of liquorice, molasses, coffee surrogate on celery basis. Taste is bitter, almost a bit tart, roasty-spicy malty, notes of roasted barley, hints of burnt coffee, burnt caramel, liquorice, a touch of molasses, coffee surrogate, raisin, blueberry, some hop bitterness. Unbalanced, harsh, more burnt than just roasty flavouring material.

Bottle. It pours a dark brown color with a beige head and lacing. The aroma is toffee, brown sugar, and hops. The taste is burnt sugar, molasses, raisins, and nice hop bitterness. The sweetness is subtle and balanced really nicely with the hop and coffee bitterness.

7.2%ABV. IPA.

Poured out dark brown. 32ºSRM.

Nose is dank and moist and nutty and suggesting boiled peanuts. Freshly roasted chestnuts. Maybe hint of wet tobacco leaf.

Mouthfeel is nutty and drip coffee. Palate is Folger’s drip coffee with smoky, slightly sour, bitter, but light without the intensity of serious carmelization. Hops are almost resinous. There is slightly sour middle-hind palate that suggests lemon peel or grapefruit peel with a slightly oily character suggesting citrus oil, which is both tangy but also with a lingering aromatic component to it.

Finish is medium long with charcoal, resin, sap.

Overall, would not characterize this as a hoppy brown. The only brown ale component comes through most obviously in the nose and the hind palate with some nutty, dark barley toast like flavors, but over all the OBVIOUS flavor notes are charcoal, burnt twigs, burnt coffee beans of a stout and the aromatics of an IPA.
Deep brown with small, light brown head. Poor head retention and lacing. Roasted malts aroma, nuts, some sugary-like notes, coffee, cocoa. In overall not that bad, above average, keeps the level.

Klares braun schöner cremiger schaum; malzig röstmalz im geruch leicht Kaffee leicht hopfen, recht süß malzig etwas Rosine etwas Kaffee röstmalz ein Hauch Kakao herb säuerlicher Abgang wobei sich dann eine leichte hopfennote auf der zunge hält , mir durchgehend etwas zu süß aber nicht übel

Aroma: Chocolate and coffee with malty backbbone
Appearance: Nice brown color
Taste: Dark coffee/chocolate/molassas
Palate: Medium body with medium carbonation
Overall: A bit harsh for my palate for a brown, but for style rates well

Piana średnio oczkowa, niezbyt trwała. Barwa brązowa, klarowna. W aromacie karmel, brązowy cukier, zioła i resztki chmielu. W smaku półsłodkie, karmelowe, w tle trochę pikantnych przypraw, orzechów, kawy zbożowej, w kontrze niska, tytoniowa goryczka. Wysycenie średnie, dość pijalne i gładkie w odbiorze.


Przeciętne Brown Ale, mocno karmelowe i z mało intensywnym zapachem. Gdzieś ten zapowiadany amerykański charakter IPA uleciał w transporcie...

33,5 cl bottle, bottled 19/11/16. Surprising seems to be the word for this beer. Surprisingly dark beer, dark brown to almost black with a good beige head. The aroma is surprisingly roasty coffee, chocolate, dark malt, dark sugar, a very light pepperness. The taste is like a suckerpunch to the head after the good smell. Sour. Very light body, overly carbonated. Taste has some coffee that was left on the burner all night, sour red fruits kind of riding over everything. Is that the ginger or is it a bad bottle? This is pretty awful. Bad surprise.

update 23.3.2017: Much better. Nutty, malty with a bit of chocolate and a good hop bite in the finish.

Bottle (as Indian Brown Dark IPA from beergium). Pours dark ruby with light beige head. Aroma is some fruits and malts. Flavor is sweet and bitter, malt, fruits, cocoa, molass, sugar. Finish has some sugar, hops. Alcohol seems mostly covered. Overall: ok.

Poured from bottle dated 12/5/16 brown with reddish hues and a thin tan head. Aromas of roasted malt chocolate toffee and burnt grain. Taste is malty with oaky sweetness sd nice mouthfeel and a lingering bitter finish.

Bottle. Black with Reddish tinge. Malty; roast malts, lots of chocolate and coffee, burnt roast, caramelized brown sugar. Hoppy; grassy and earthy hops. Sweet malty with nice bitter hoppy edge. Probably unique. Certainly interesting. An unusual and decent beer. (2008)
Tap at Dogfish Head, Milton. Colour is clear brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Chocolate, some nuts, hops and malts. Pretty good.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Kawa, brązowy cukier, resztki chmielu.

roasty light coffee aroma. dark red/brown in color with nice long lasting head with a tinge of light brown to it. taste is of very dark caramel malts, roasted barley, coffee, and faint hints of chocolate.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate and some hops. Tastes rather thin, otherwise nice.
Started drinking it too cold. It was 10 degrees in my garage. As it warmed, I loved this beer. Chocolate and coffee on the nose. Nothing like a dark IPA, don’t know why it’s named what it is.

Keg at Barcade, St Marks Place, Manhattan. Dark brown with some translucency. A gorgeous cream-coloured head leaves lots of lacing. Very little aroma: some resin, some soft citrus, some oak. Taste is much more pronounced: the malty sweetness and oaky umami combine with a well-judged fresh hop bitterness. Slight metallic note in the long finish. A mixed bag, but a mixed bag at a high level. Imminently quaffable.
Aromas of lemon and grapefruit, with wet leaves and hazelnut chocolate. Taste is hazelnut, milk chocolate, raisin skin, grapefruit, then a moderate piney hop bite with some wet leaves.
Appearance is a deep brown. Aroma is rich malts. Taste is nicely balanced between lightly bitter hops and sweet malts. Overall very good.

Kólaszínű teste a kitöltést követően egészen feketébe hajlik, kakaóporos, rumos csokoládés, kávés, de leginkább nápolyis aromákkal van szegélyezve. Ízvilága remekül közvetíti a diós, földimogyoró-krémes, étcsokoládé bevonatos, ostyás mondanivalót, éppoly intenzív, mint az illata. Szerkezete jól passzol mindehhez, a közepes test visszafogott szénsavtartalommal párosulva kiváló terep a sötét csemege feltérképezéséhez. Kivételes brown ale, emlékezetes Dogfish Head darab.

12oz bottle at home. No BB date. dark brown color, small tan head. smells of caramel, spices, plums, marzipan, nutty, hints of exotic fruits. nice smell. full body, light carbonation, soft mouthfeel. tastes nutty, some licorice, spices, bit earthy, marzipan, plums, light raisins, bit milky, hints of cardboard. finishes lightly sweet with notes of spices, raisins and light cardboardish notes. quite decent beer, but also a bit on the heavy side.

Brown body with off white head. Aromas of malt,bread,esters,pear.Tastes malt,bread,yeast(?).It is sweet at first and bitter athe end of the sip.The body is medium.A nice interpretation of the American Brown Ale style.A very complex,deep beer with character.

Pours medium to dark brown, medium light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, raisins, sweet malt. Taste is malt forward, sweet, cocoa, some hops. Medium mouthfeel. A nice beer as we slide into cooler weather.

16 oz pour on draft at Hilton McLean Tysons Corner’s Härth Bar. Clear brownish amebr with beige head. Aromas of malt, caramel, light roast. Tastes of malt, caramel, light cocoa, floral. Medium body with a dry finish.

The aroma smells a bit like molasses and the appearance is a rich brown. The taste is a little sweet with a nice mild hoppy finish. I have not had many variations of this beer type and found this selection to be fantastic!

Very good brown ale! Sweet with a little spice. They really mixed this one up and it all blended nicely. The scotch ale comes through wonderfully. High ABV goes unnoticed, maybe the slight sweetness is the reason for that. It’s an easy, enjoyable brew.

Deep brown beer with a nice, medium head. Aroma of walnut leaves, caramel, raisins, waffles, chocolate. Seems drier in the taste that it actually is with medium carbonation and an interesting, medium bitter walnut finish. The flavours are pretty the same with a solid touch of american hops. And here is a snag because the latter at some point stand out too much in a perfume fashion. Nevertheless, the beer is a really decent brown ale IPA specimen.

Bottle - average size foamy head, very dark brown color, pretty sweet caramel aroma and flavor, some dark fruit/raisin like flavors in there too, fair size hop balance, sweet finish, good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aromas a caramelo, malta, notas dulces y ligeramente ahumadas.

De color rojizo con tonos granates. Corona de espuma abundante de buena retencion. Carbonatacion media.

En boca, notas a caramelo, maltosa y con final seco y amargo.

Al paladar deja muy buen sabor de boca. Al principio sobresalen las motas a malta, grano y caramelo, para dar paso a un final seco y amargo.

En general es bastante buena, quizá no tam apegada al estilo por el amargor tan intenso, pero muy rica.

Pours dark brown. Aroma of rich brown sugar, caramel and molasses. There's little hop aroma to speak of (in this bottle at least - bottled 8 months before drinking). Hops come through nicely in the flavour but again I was expecting a hit of hops. All in all though it is a brilliant brown ale which I would definitely drink again.

Amber-brown. Thin tan head. 
Caramel, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla aromas. 
Mostly sweet and bitter throughout. 
Malty flavors. Syrup, bread. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours an opaque brown with a fading light beige bubbly head. Aroma is of molasses, ginger, chocolate, nuts, slight bitterness. Taste is of ginger, chocolate, Nutella, grassy, caramel. Light oily mouthfeel, soft to medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours dark brown, cola highlights and a low beige head. Big full aroma of caramelised brown sugar, chocolate. Rich and sweet. The flavour is similar, almost too strong in its sweet caramel and molasses, cacao, kinda overpowering any hop notes. The hops do integrate well with bitterness combining well with fizzy carbonation and smooth malt. Decent overall.

sample from bottle, poured a deep amber to brown colour with a tanned head on top.nose of sweet caramel malts, toffee, light cacao, molasses, nuts, and slight roast. taste is sweet with a sticky mouthfeel.

On tap at Brewski. A dark hazel hue with chocolate, molasses, and hops on the nose. A tasty brew with a bit more zing on the palate than a standard brown ale, but still a fairly dry finish. Excellent.

From the bottle the pour is dark brown with and as light passes through a little red. The head is light brown, thick and lingures. The aroma is cream notes of toffee and coffee. The taste is roasted, slightly smoked. Quickly brightens with the hops and finished roasted and bitter. Overall impression is the beer is dark but a good balance of hops that make it feel less heavy but a solid brown.
355ml bottle from The Perfect Pour. Pours a reddish brown with a medium tan head. Aromas of malt, nuts, hops. Taste is coffee, malt, nuts, sweet up front and bitter to finish.
chocolate, coffee, nuts, grass, citrus, herbs, red, clear, tan foam, salty, medium bitterness, medium sweetness, lightly sour, medium body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter and salty finish.

Pours up a medium dark brown with a moderate tan head. Rich roasted malt aroma with caramel and toffee. Smooth and creamy texture. Full bodied taste with roasted malts and nuts, caramel and toffee. Smooth finish. Not much hop presence. Moderately sweet. Very enjoyable.
Pours dark nutty brown. Aroma is malty, slight roasted, bread. Taste os malty, roasted, coffee, hoppy balance.

Bottle 12 oz. Pours dark copper with tan head, good retention. Aroma of coffee, dark fruits, dark sugar, roasted malts, licorice. A bitter taste with some sweetness in the aftertaste. Notes of brown sugar, dark fruits, caramel, alcohol is noticeable. Oily texture and average carbonation.

(Ancient tasting notes from backlog; 355 ml bottle from Kihoskh; BBD: June 8th 2013 09:19) Poures dark copper with creamy tan head that fades to leave a film and beautiful lace. Aroma has notes of toasted malt with nutty hints. Oily texture, soft carbonation, medium body with a moderately sweet but boozy finish. Flavour is well balanced with initial sweetness and subsequent bitter hoppiness.

Bottle, 355ml. A dark reddish beer with a small white head. Aroma is of caramel, brown sugar and roasted malt. Taste is moderately bitter with a toasted finish. Medium bodied with some carbonation. Sweet caramel finish with molasses.

Bottle, 355ml. Sparkling reddish with a frothy to minimal tan head. Aromas of caramel, nuts, dried fruits, brown sugar. Medium to robust bodied with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet, medium to heavy bitter. Deep roasted character into a fruity and alcohol finish. Very pleasant.

Slightly smokey roasted malt and chocolate aromas from a crystal clear medium brown/cola colored body with a thin white head. Creamy texture with lots of milk and dark chocolate notes and husky grain flavor. A subtle but noticeable molasses and brown sugar taste at the end in the back of the mouth. Nicely balanced earthy bitterness that keeps this really interesting. Finishes with all these flavors lasting long after the final sip. This is anything but a run-of-the-mill brown ale. Tasty, delicious and complex.

A total miss for me. The hopiness totally overpowered the roasted malty notes one looks for in a brown ale. The overall effect was a bitter, confused mess of a brew. I may end up pouring the rest of the 6-pack down the drain.
Very malty, quite sweet, plenty of toffee. Thick palate, alcohol noticeable. Really satisfying beer - shame I had to gulp half of it down because of an incorrect TV screen in the airport.

Well, color me ’old and in the way’, because I’m really not digging this brewer’s mish-mash. They seem proud of the fact that it’s a little bit of this and a little bit of that, but for me, the mixup doesn’t work at all. I like some scotch ales, which can be quite delicious, I drink a lot of IPA’s and the occasional APA, but trying to make a Franken-brew out of spare parts and caramelized brown sugar... yowch! ’DeScriptors: Notes of molasses, coffee, ginger, raisinettes, chocolate’. Uh huh. I don’t like it. Mix up some coffee, molasses, ginger, raisinettes and chocolate, throw in some brown sugar and you get some very odd flavored candy. Not a drain pour, but close.
First Indian brown ale, nice malts and hops. Good carbonation, full bodied. Will try again

Pours a clear lovely dark brown. Aroma of roasted malts and brown sugar and caramel. Tastes darker than a traditional brown - rich with caramel and toffee and molasses. Perfect carbonation and just enough hops for balance. Definitely more than 2/3 of the way to a porter. An excellent brown.

Ar- toasty malts, hints of chocolate and caramel, subtle burnt toast, low hop aroma

Ap- pours a clear dark brown, nice tan head, good looking beer

Fl- light malt sweetness up front is very well balance with roasty and hop bitterness. Hints of toffee, caramel, toasted almonds, nice bittersweet aftertaste. 

Mf- full bodied, perfectly carbonated, dry, mild alcohol warming

Ov- very nice beer, well balanced and delicious. I want another :)

Bottle. Pours a red brown color with an off white head. Aroma and taste of malts, caramel and fruits with notes of nuts. Hoppy finish.

From a 12 ounce bottle. Pours dark with minimal head. Aroma is sweet malty and coffee/toffee. Drinks medium to light with slightly bitter coffee hoppy flavor. Drinks like a stout or porter more than a brown.

I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass.  It pours a dark brown color with a beige head and lacing.  The aroma is toffee, brown sugar, and hops.  The taste is burnt sugar, molasses, raisins, and nice hop bitterness. The sweetness is subtle and balanced really nicely with the hop and coffee bitterness. This is a really nice beer.

Draft.

Nice appearance, dark brown with beige head. Taste finished with hint of coffee.
Cask pour at the brewery. Creamy texture, smooth slick, roast chocolate with an underlying bitter bite. Nice to see a brown ale with some snap to it.
Poured from 12 fl oz bottle. Dark brown with beige head. Toasted malt, mild nuts, hint of caramel and sweet chocolate, subtle hops.
Pours brown with reddish hue. Aroma of roasted nuts and malts. Earthy taste with medium bitterness.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby-brown with thin tan head. Raisins and alcohol on the nose. Raisins and molasses with subtle smoked malt notes. Mouthcoating, long finish.

Bottle. Brown with a reddish tinge, small white head and heavy lacing. Golden syrup, chocolate and earthy hop aromas. Flavours of sweet brown sugar, cola and coffee with an earthy hop finish. Typical brown ale, slightly watery mouthfeel. The sugar was overdone for me.

On bottle from Kihosk, Copenhagen. Brown color, ok foam. Medium/high aroma intensity; roasty, leather, some hops, malt and dried fruits. Medium/full body & complexity. Good bitterness and balance. Very enjoyable

Poured from a bottle. Pours a medium dark mahogany brown with a thin tan ring. Nice rich roasted sweet malt aroma. Smooth and creamy texture. Full bodied with roasted malts and nuts. Lingering flavors with a smooth finish. Very enjoyable. Not the best Brown I’ve had but very good.

Pours dark brown with an off white head. Nose is west coast hops and a touch of roasted malt. Flavor is rich chocolate and roasted malts with a greatfloral hop balance. FFinish is bittersweet and sticky. This is basically a gentle black IPA, not a brown ale.

Marrom avermelhado, espuma de media formação e persistência. Café espresso, açucar mascavo, torrado, um pouco de frutas secas escuras. Paladar de leve dulçor, médio amargor. Floral, spicy hop aroma with notes of chocolate and licorice. Clear brown appearance with a tan head. Flavor is has toasted bread with light roasted notes with notes of caramel. Hop bitterness is high with a spicy floral character. Mouthfeel is medium with a medium carbonation ale. Overall, it's a great tasting American brown ale

Bottle approx 4 months old. Subdued hop character so more dominated by malt - sweet, raisin, chocolate. Well balanced, mild bitterness. Overall a complex and enjoyable brown ale, would like to try a fresher bottle to compare.

Shared 12 oz. bottle. Dark brown and clear with a light tan head. Nose is sweet roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and caramel. Similar flavor, with brown sugar sweetness, a hint of scotch, and mild hop bitterness. Much more personality than the average brown.

Aroma: malty, hoppy and sweet; very nice; Appearance: dark reddish amber with fluffy head that dissipates quickly; a little lacing; Taste: very malty and smooth; coffee and caramel undertones; only negative is a slight sourness that isn’t entirely pleasant; Palate: heavy body with long, sweet finish; Overall: great beer; would definitely buy again.

Pours a clear reddish brown with a thin tan head. Sweet malt aroma of caramel and brown sugar with light apricot and hops. Sugary malts up front and floral hops in the finish. Interesting combo of sweet brown ale and a pale ale.

Cherry cola color with minimal head. Huge aroma of toffee, coffee, toasted malts, raisins, nuts, and caramel. Flavor follows aroma with spurts of piney hops and bittering. Mild carbonation and smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is raisins, heavy bread, chocolate, burnt sugar. Taste is bitter up front with slight sweetness on the finish. Extremely balanced! Unique concoction and very drinkable.

Pours a half finger of head on a clear brown body.
The aroma is toast (almost burnt), wood, brown sugar, caramel and raisins.
The taste roasted malt, then some pine bitterness, big dose of caramel sweet and a bite of grapefruit to finish.
The texture is crisper.
It’s pretty good.

Bottle bought @ Kihoskh. Pours hazy brown with a small frothy beige head that quickly dissipates while leaving lots of spotty sticky trace on the glass. Smell is malty, grassy and tiny fruity with dark bread, caramel, chocolate fudge, grapefruit juice, moist grass, pine needles, moist soil and lemon zest. Taste is sweet. bitter, malty, grassy, earthy and tiny fruity. Mouthfeel is soft, round, tiny astringent and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with dark bread, caramel, grapefruit juice, moist grass, pine needles, cocoa powder, moist soil, lemon zest and hints of cardboard. Solid hoppy brown if a bit old with faded hops. Solid but had higher hopes.
Una gran combinación entre IPA y Brown Ale. Notas a nuez y caramelo en nariz, tiene un amargor moderado, hace sentir el lúpulo sin incomodar. Gran cerveza, peligrosamente bebible.

I love the smell of coffee and hate the taste of it. This beer is a pint of cold coffee in smell and in taste, and because it’s so strong on the coffee notes, it’s not palatable to someone like me. I can appreciate the craft here, but I can’t drink this beer.

Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale can best be described as IPA meets really good brown ale. Dark brown pour with a light tan head that sticks. Aroma is hoppy, nutty and roasty. Taste is nutty caramel flavor with just enough hop kick. IBA hits all the right notes to give a tremendously balanced brew.
Bottle 12fl.oz. Small light brown head leaving. Dark brown clear color. Aroma is berries, chocolate, leather, sugary leaves and wood. Taste is sweet of berries and sugar. Hops still very present.

Draught at the Beavertown Brewery taproom on 26-Sep-2015 as part of the Rainbow Project. Good brown colour with a tan coloured bead. Softly carbonated. Flavour of caramel, coffee, malt and hops. A really nice imperial brown ale with a lot of flavour.
Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a cloudy head. Smells like burnt caramel. Taste a bit of coffee with a dark roast aftertaste. Mouth feel was okay.
12oz bottle poured right down my gullet. Aromas of brown ale roastiness, chocolate malt, and caramel. Mild to medium bitter. Tasty.
Keg at craftbeercalling. Pours black with a decent foamy head. Coffee and roasted malts aroma. Strong roasted malts, some chicory and a hint of fresh brewed coffee.

Pours a dark brown from a bottle. Aroma of espresso and molasses, flavor similar except brown sugar added into the mix. Wish I was tasting those raisinets, that sounds interesting, but I’m just not getting it. Good beer.

Bottled, poured into glass. A really solid brown ale. Nice nose, big malt body, and a beautiful finish. Very easy drinking but full of flavor. Great stuff.

hazy cocoa brown with thin beige lacing. Chocolate orange nose, moderate body and carbonation, pithy citrus and toasty cocoa& coffee notes, dry but brief finish...more brown ale than iba...not as hopped as expected

Opaque brown turbidity with no head. Pungent dark chocolate, malt, scotch, caramel, vanilla, roast, and dried fruit aroma. Truly outstanding scent. Light bodied and quite smooth. Keg at magic rock, pours dark chocolate brown, off white head. Aroma is chocolate malt, roasted toffee, hop spice, citrus hop. Nice balance of different flavours. Very tasty.

Slikket bajer, dog i en svært kedelig flaske. Ikke imponeret over designet. Duften en smule røget, lidt a la brunt værtshus og læder møbler balsameret med nikotin. Smager let af malt og kaffe, samt jeg tror der er nok sukker i til at de er sponsoreret af Dansukker. Udemærket.

Origin: Tap. Vessel: Tulip. Supplier: Small Bar (Bristol). Sour with hint of cherry. Smoky aftertaste.

On tap at Beavertown Rainbow Project 2015, Tottenham, London. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Roasty, malty, coffee, caramel aroma. Tastes similar, roasty, malty, chocolate, coffee, caramel. Nicely complex, a great effort from Dogfish Head.

Keg at Rainbow event at Beavertown, London. It pours a clean brown color with medium beige head. Aroma is lightly roasty and grainy with dried leaves. Taste is lightly dry and biscuity with more notes of dried leaves earth and nuts. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, decent

Bottle. Appearance: Deep brown, clear, with a thick mousse like khaki head.

Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of dark sweet malts, toffee, hazelnut, caramel and some vanilla. The taste is sweet with some weak hoppy notes. Also some bitter nuts, sweet malts, weak raisin, toffee and coffee.

On tap at the brewpub. A dark brown beer, unclear, and topped by a dark beige head. It’s roasted and lightly piney on the nose, some coffee and a touch of the alcohol. Tap at Verdugo. Bit spicy, chocolate, light bitterness, smooth. Didn’t write much it seems.

May 9, 2015. Bottle at home, bottled march 13, 2014. /i>

Deep ruby red with dense off-white head. Aroma is nutty, caramel, figs, slight notes of hard gingerbread.
Taste is medium sweet toffee, nuts, light to medium bitterness with a roasted note. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Not a lot of hops but a very solid brown ale.

12 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 10/15/2014. Pours crystal clear dark reddish brown color with a 1 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, toast, dark bread, molasses, light dark fruit, herbal, grass, light pine, and roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roasted/bready malt and moderate earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, toast, dark bread, molasses, light dark fruit, herbal, grass, pine, and roast/toasted earthiness. Fair amount of herbal/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, molasses, herbal, grass, light pine, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome hoppy brown ale style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.
Very nice brown ale. Not as strong as expected, but nice sweet aroma with good mouth feel and balanced taste. Hops are subtle but provide a tempering of the sweetness.

Bottled on 1/21/09....Sampled on 5/13/09, poured into a wider wine glass. This beer pours thick with a medium lace. A dark brown-near black color. Medium carbonation, but didn’t produce that much of a head. I can’t stop sipping it! The flavors are outstanding, mainly sweet, but with a slight hoppy aftertaste. Thinking of the Rolling Stone’s song, "Brown Sugar", as that is the main theme going on here. It’s almost like a stout. Aroma is oak mixed with the sweets of the malts and sugar. Reminds me of a toned down, affordable version of the DFH Immort Ale, which is like 11% vs. 7.2% here. They only had one left at the local retailer, but I’ll be looking out for more of this in the future.
UPDATE: Bottled on 11/29/07 (sampled on 6/12/09)........Bought a 6-pack of this after loving the first single/sample I tried. I didn’t really notice this until I drank the 4th one, that this may have aged a bit too long. Had a bit more of a sour taste, where that sweet balanced taste I liked maybe had fermented too much. I did notice the hops a little more though, which I guess is a good thing. Still tasted good and sweet, and was totally drinkable, just didn’t seem how I preferred it before. Maybe it was just that this bottle was starting to turn, I dunno. I wouldn’t let this one age much more than a year, just to be safe.

Lately I’ve really been into Indian Red Ales so maybe I picked this up at the wrong time. I love a good brown, but this combo just didn’t do it for me in the end. It’s a nice beer, but it probably would have been nicer with less of a hop character. Tasty anyways just not my favorite mash-up.
Old rating. Hazy brown pour. Roasted malts, coffee, caramel, with some hop brightnessz balance isn't entirely in check, but still an interesting decent brown.

12 pour from refrigerated bottle into a Spiegelau stout glass. Allowed to warm for a bit. Strong last. Moderate lacing and fairly strong retention. Brown or maybe dark ruby. Mostly opaque-- a tiny bit of transparency. Carbonation looks good. Nose is sugary, malty, and a little woody. Mouthfeel is a little weak, but mostly creamy. Taste is awesome. Scotch ale sweetness, brown ale maltiness, and a nice hoppy bitterness at the end. A bit of coffee and molasses. There?s a lot going on-- a bit hard for me to dissect the flavors. Great complexity.
March Madness 2015 - A nice brown ale but a really sour finish that is overpowering. So much potential but it doesn’t work for me.

March madness 2015. The aroma is not strong with coffee the most dominant contributor. The ale itself is smooth with good roasted malt notes. The roasted malt and hops work together nicely. The finish is not overly bitter.
Really decent brown ale with great caramel look, smell, and taste. Off white head sticks around with lacing all the way down. Really enjoyed this Dogfish Head version.
35 cl bottle @ home. Pours clear reddish brown with a white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma and flavour are toffee, caramel, and dried fruit - with a slightly dry finish.

12oz bottle from Mitsuya’s poured into a tulip pint. Pours a dark chocolate brown color with a big beige head. Nice lacing. Sorghum, brown sugar, prune, currants and roasted grain on the nose. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied leaning to the sweet side of the palate. As it warms up the fruit really stands out. Really solid brown ale.
Nose is dark bread/sweet. Flavor is same plus orange marmalade, mild citrus rind, roast, nutty, caramel accents, pine accents. Solid.
Couleur brune foncé avec un col beige respectable. Aromes de noix,caramel,herbes,café. Respectable mais rien d’incroyable!

12oz bottle poured into a belgian tulip. The aroma is a malty chocolate and roasty coffee initially, but the chocolate fades. Coffee aromas remain in the form of fresh beans and are joined by earthy grains, brown sugar / molasses, gingersnap cookies, and raisins. The beer is crystal clear, oily, and lightly effervescent with a deep, dark, and rich caramel brown hue. It’s topped by an off-white, soapy head that retains a thick ring, a frothy foamy surface, a leaves a moderate, messy lace. The beer is a balanced, medium bittersweet. It’s smooth with a light, prickly carbonation, and a medium body. Lightly smokey flavors of raisin and cooked brown sugar merge with coffee and a light biscuit biscuit note on the palate. It finishes with a syrupy chocolate, roasted coffee, and cooked brown sugar blend, as well as a light charred note. The aftertaste is lightly astringent as well as cloying with a sticky sugar character, and light flavors of coffee, clean ginger, and bread.

Relatively unique experience. Not sure if it is a good unique or not. Can clearly get traits from both the malty scotch style and the hoppier IPA/pale ale styles. I typically like the complex brews but this is almost too much to hold together. Definitely not something i can drink often. A rather confusing drink for me. Each sip seemed to taste different so i can’t quite figure this one out.

E’ dì un bel colore marrone scuro, molto intenso, con riflessi rossastri; la schiuma è poco presente, fine e di colore beige. L’aroma è interessante, complesso, pulito e raffinato. In evidenza cioccolato, caffè, tostature, sentori terrosi, prugne disidratate, zucchero di canna, melassa. Il gusto non si discosta di molto, riproponendo note di tostatura, caffè, leggero cioccolato, uvetta, prugne secche. Ha un corpo medio, una carbonazione contenuta ed è molto gradevole e morbida in bocca, lasciandosi bere molto facilmente. Alcool non pervenuto, appagante retrogusto lungo e morbido di caffè e di cioccolato.

From bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a beige head and nice lacing on the glass. Aroma has coffee and lightly roasted malts. Taste has a gentle sweetness, roasted malts, just a hint of smoke, coffee. Medium mouthfeel.

12 oz Bottle. Appearance is dark caramel color with tons of foamy, beige head. Aroma is roasted grains, sugar, raisins, and citrus. Taste is similar with lots of dark fruit sweetness, caramel, followed on a citrus hop bitterness - also very acidic. Palate is light-bodied, thin texture, lively carbonation, and semi-dry finish. I’m not sure what I’m missing with this one, but it just didn’t sit well with me. Too acidic. Flavors contradictory and all over the map. I felt like it was trying to do too much.

Bottle from cellarbrations super store in hami hill. Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is slight citrus, lemon and toffee. Body is medium
With low carbonation. Taste begins quite sweet like molasses which turns into some citrus. Finish is quite big and ends with a coffee bitterness coupled with some nutty hints. Hops come to life as it gets warmer with grapefruit and some mango appearing. Had this back to back with Samuel smiths nut brown. This definetly had much more bolder flavours with more hop character coming through. Nice beer!

On draft. Nice malty, coffee aroma. Deep brown color, nice tan head with pretty lacing. Don’t really taste the hops, but maybe it’s a subtle edge to the maltiness that balances really well. Creamy. Coffee after taste. Nice beer.
Roasted malt and coffee flavor. Creamy mouthful and not much of a hops presence. Pretty good brown ale.

Aroma is an interesting cappuccino up front with some brown sugar and roasted malt when you explore it further. No hops at all in the scent; strange for dogfish head. Bottle, 355 ml from deli in Brooklyn. Pours brown with small off-white head. Roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, nuts. Sweet. Medium body.

bottle from kihoskh. rare event that i get to rate a bottle with 2000+ ratings on it. clear dark amber nutty bruwn.aroma is like really good belgian quad, raisins, dark dried fruits, faint nutty note, malts, but also below the complexity a dose of us hops that gives a sweet sawdusty base to the aroma. Bottle into snifter. Very dark ruby brown almost black. Thin head. Almost no aroma which is a disappointment. Some mild malty biscuit aroma and taste. Mild sweet caramel notes. Full mouthfeel and flavor. Smooth. Decent beer.

Bottle: Pours a reddish brown with a beige head. The aroma was caramel and molasses. The creamy taste was well balanced with plenty of malt and hop flavor and slightly sweet at the end.

Pours a dark clear amber color with some ruby in it. The head is tan and rather thick and foamy and left plenty of lacing around the glass. The aroma is dark fruits, caramel, raisins, mildly bitter chocolate, and some brown sugar. The taste is very rich and very good. You have the typical brown ale flavors such as nuts, caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, some dark fruit, and mild coffee yet on the back end I pick up the hops that are added and some even mild citrus and hop oil resin. This is definitely a world class beer that I highly recommend.

Pours deep garnet brown with a small light tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel, and toffee. All sorts of roasty malty goodness. Pours a deep red brown. Floral and sweet nose. Beautiful balance between the malt and hops. Piney finish. A great beer.

A - very dark brown, near black, with mahogany highlights. Large tan head with good duration. 

Aroma: medium and dark roasted malts; perhaps a slight hop spiciness. ABV well hidden but with a floral note. 

T: rich malt flavor leading to a lasting malty finish and aftertaste. Hops make their presence known mainly in the clear bitterness of the finish. Higher ABV becomes evident after warming.

O - a rich and malty brew, with well hidden higher ABV and a lasting dark malt aftertaste. An East Coast lower-hop Rogue.

A: Black.

355ml Bottle as a gift from Virginia:

Medium to dark copper & clear with a light, tan brown head that’s slightly foamy & about a 0.5cm tall with little initial movement.


Sweet & nutty with sugar & caramel coming through. Medium strength malts are there with hints of hops giving the beer a definite American style aroma. Darker fruits/raisins with some further sweetness, hints of chocolate & light bitterness come through as well.

DATE REVIEWED: August 8, 2014... GLASSWARE: Barley Creek pint... OCCASION: Watching Return of the King with a worthy beer... APPEARANCE: Wow--allows a look through its body only when held to light--glass is black as a Wraith; the head is two-fingered, off-white and thick.. AROMA: wonderfully balanced: hoppy and citric, with raisin and plum, yet toasted with biscuit... the malts predominate, with a hint of roasted nuts and caramel--intense and robust ... PALATE: thick, creamy, and rather soft in ts carbonation--that classic cola mouth feel; slightly bitter at its end ... TASTE: the aroma sets this beer’s flavor, as dense, blanketed hops give way to unsweetened chocolate and toasted rye bread--a wondrously stout yet drinkable brown, that only hints at the alcohol it wields... OVERALL: what a drink with which to welcome crisp fall nights--strong, stern and warming, yet balanced, complex and highly drinkable...another victory for Sam and the guys at DFH...

At cellar temperature and into a snifter. Had no idea what to expect of style so a cool temperature seemed apt. Deepest, darkest brown and opaque with a fine, tight bead and a thin pad of sandy cream atop. Big waft of cocoa and rpasted carob dominates the nose with minor licks of tangerine, cola and root beer, burnt toast and burnt, savoury raisins. Creamy mouthfeel, velvety even. Rounded, sumptuous body with a smooth finish. Chocolate malts dominate here as the nose. A tannic, dark berry note in back gives it a fruity element and then it is all dusty cocoa powder, carob and chocolate icecream in the finish. Light rust and blood, a higher, heated alcohol kick and plenty of wood and peanut husks in the aftertaste give it complexity. This is a nice brew. More Brown ale than Scotch ale and by no means showing any inkling of IPA. Great drinking though! (12fl.Oz, Bottled on 05/07/14, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)

Reviewed from notes. 
I’ve had this in pint glasses and a couple times in tulips. It’s always the same. 
The appearance was a nice dark brown color with a decent one finger white foamy head that dissipates within about a minute and left some light semi - thick lacing in its wake. 
The smell was awesome as it had a super nice allocation of the Scottish peat - like smokey/roasty malts to the engraving bittersweet citrus hops to delightfully entice my nose to partake in more whiffs to get some light roasty caramel nuttiness about it.

From BA review on 2-5-12 - 
Poured from bottle into pint glass.

Appearance – Pours a deep-brown color. Upon pouring there is a billowy tan head which forms which slowly fades over time to produce some nice lacing and a very thin persistent foam film on the top of the brew.

Smell – A huge caramel aroma meets the nose. While overwhelming at first, it gives away a bit, revealing aromas of roasty malt and a bit of nuttiness and some alcohol.

Taste – A semi-sweet malt flavor first hits, which seems to sweeten over time giving way to a very caramely flavor and some brown sugar. A roasted malt flavor with nice toasted nut and a little bit of of coffee flavors round out the taste, leaving a rather satisfying taste in the mouth.

Mouthfeel – The thicker body suits this beer quite nice. Mixed with the slightly linger carbonation it allows the brew to linger on the tongue; creating a very nice mouthfeel. 

Overall – This is one very nice beer. While not the most potent, the sweet maltiness mixed with the thicker mouthfeel and roasty flavor make this a great brew to sit and sip slowly over a relaxing evening.
Bottle - Nutty flavor, malt and a little bit of hops on this one. Kind of a woody taste as well. While it does have a high alcohol content, it doesn't taste of alcohol.

Smokey taste with a slight scotch finish.

Flaske, 355 ml. Mahognybrun. Maltet næse. Sødlig opvaskevand. Letristet malt. Brød. Chocolade. Ikke dårlig eller ublanceret, men vil alt for meget på een gang - ofte et problem med Dogfish Head. Kedelig prog-øl.

Excellent brew. Has a sweet, malty aroma with a slight hint of hops. Great color brown that is as clear as brown can get. The flavor slowly creeps across your toungue and leaves a light bitter finish.

Draft at Belmont Station. While I despise the IPA label being reassigned to any hoppy beer from red to brown, I am willing to forgive Dogfish Head both due to their brewing excellence and the fact that despite the ’pale’ in IPA it historically most likely resembled the blood-red brown of this beer, Carmel-colored with thick head and dark lace. Alcohol, dark berries, and earthy hops in the nose, thick and slightly-cloying mouthfeel with rich malt, alcohol esters, and back-tongue bitterness in the middle, and eatery-fruity malt and satisfying bitterness at the end, finishing in malt rather than citrus or astringent. Excellent example of a historical IPA, regardless of label.
Brown in color. Aroma of hops and roasted malt. Interesting mix. Taste is fruity and caramel. Slightely bitter aftertaste
Dark with slight head. Sweet aroma. Reminds me of a coffee stout. Not quite a true scotch ale, but not bad.

Bottle from Kihoskh shared with esp0r and edvard, april 26th 2014. Dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma of burned malt, fruity hops, chocolate. Taste is light roasted with thick caramelized malt, flowery oand fruity hops, and quite high bitterness.

Bottle from Sugaya. It pours a rich ruby brown that looks somewhat stout like in the glass butappearance wise I’d say is closer to a Belgian dark ale like a Rochefort 8 or 10. The nose is soft chocolate & toffee with a citrusy hop presence - pretty good. The beer has a medium body & a somewhat syrupy mouthfeel. The taste is quite good, roasty, cacao paste, figs, bitter coffee grinds & playing with these malt flavors are some candy sweetness & citrusy hops. Pretty good but Belgians do it better.

This dark chocolate colored beer pours a thick tan head that lingers. It has a nutty aroma with a hint of burnt sugar. The taste is reminiscent of the same and with the rich malted barley and high IBU from the dry hops it is nutty, sweet, and bitter all at once. The alcohol is high enough that it really becomes prominent as the beer comes to room temperature, so drink this one quickly.

Clear medium rubyish brown. Large frothy creamy tan head, partly lasting. Aroma is quite malty. Burnt roasty malty. Molasses. Nutty. Chocolate. Caramel. Coffee. Flavor is dusty cocoa mostly. Earthy hops. Medium body. Dry. Medium creamy. Lightly acidic. Mild bitterness. Roasty dry finish. Complex and still easy drinking. Puts the typical brown ale to shame.

Sweet malt, chocolate, dark roast, dark fruit, roasty aroma. Caramel, some hops. 
Medium body, roast, chocolate, caramel, molasses, hops, a slight bitter finish.

pours cola brown with a medium tan head. aroma is malty and bready. Taste is full rich malty caramel. definite coffee notes. slight bitterness and hop presence on the finish. nice fading linger. Really good beer!

12oz bottle poured into DFH signature glass. Pours a dark brown, small head that slowly disappeared, Lots of tiny bubbles rising to the top. (Bottle 22 /02-2014) Low beige head, dark brown color, caramel aroma, soft co2, fit body, rather smooth taste. Bottled 06/08/13.

This beer is not my ’cup of beer (??!!??)’ ; however, I can still tell that it is a quality brew and those that like this style will love it. FROM NOTES; July 1, ’12
Poured into a snazzy DFH pint. 

A: Not much of a hop profile on the nose, but an interesting combination of dark malts and dark fruits. Some coffee notes with a Lilliputian bitter cocoa note. 
A: Pours a crisp dark brown with a tan head that fades into some nice lacing. 
T: This beer is very complex. There are chocolate notes, but it is not a sweet beer. It’s a bitter beer, but not over-whelming due to the progression of the hop profile. The finish is a malty/creamy finish. 
P: Very creamy with just a bit of hops for this smooth, medium bodied beer.
O: A fantastic brown, its’ complexity keeps the palette guessing while maintaining a nice balance throughout. No one taste dominates another too harshly but tumbles in some sort of complementary way that makes this a beer worth having.

A: Strong malt note followed by a hop note. 
A: looks good. pour is a little thin. Head is creamy light tan. In the glass it looks thin dark brown. 
T: Hits with some medium hop flavor which builds into the middle. Finish is malty with a hint of chocolate. Very nice. Flavors clash a little in the front but develop well. Unique. A little thin. 
P: A little clash of flavors at the start. Body is light and thin. Finish is good. 

Overall this is a solid beer and it is decently unique. Fun play between hops and malt. Drinks almost like a pale ale but has a chocolate finish.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a large, lacing head. Aroma of slightly roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily text. nd soft carb. An excellent brown.

Bottle. Thanks to the mother-in-law. Pours deep brown chestnut with a large, creamy, beige head. Aroma has caramel, toasted, citrus, hazelnuts, apricot. Medium carbonation, nice dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has nice caramel, chocolate, hazelnuts. Loads of good citrussy bitterness. Very well balanced.

12 oz. bottle. It pours a nice dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is pretty intense with pleasant toasty malts, a little coffee and cocoa and mild notes of raisin in the background. The flavor is really intense with a rich dark fruity thing up front…raisins, plum and then it settles in to a more roasted malt profile with coffee and tobacco. Lots of tobacco in the finish. This was way different than I expected. I’m not getting a whole lot of hops in this one. To me, it’s more of a cross between a strong Scotch Ale and an Imperial Brown Ale. Unique beer and pretty tasty.

Chestnut coloured with a deep red tinge, medium brownish head. Aroma: Nuts, caramel, melanoids, toffee and biscuit. full bodied and fizzy with refreshing flavors of red fruits with a hoppy finish and a good bitterness and balanced sweetness.

Caramelized, roasted malts, toasted bread and nuts. Dark red brown, clear w beige head. Same as in aroma. Dried dark fruits. Not any aroma hops as I’d expected, but a nice dark brown tending to a porter.
Aroma: Caramel. liqurice, coffee, nuts. The beer has a flavour which is burned. The palate is thick and creamy

With Generous amounts of caramel, liqourice and roasted nuts this bery dark brown ale could just as will qualify as a porter.

Pours a deep brown color with a light tan head that never seems to disappear. Smells of roasted caramel, sweet and sugary. Pours a beautiful chocolate color. Aroma of brown sugar, coffee, chocolate, nuts and hop fragrances. Tastes sweet with creamy caramel and maple syrup malt tones, and bitter bite from grassy hops. Palate is silky, medium bodied.

12 oz Bottle. The beer pours to an almost black color with a medium dark tan head. The aroma has a strong coffee caramel smell to it. The taste has a heavy taste to it with a strong malt backbone. Overall a very interesting brown ale.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark chestnut color. The head is a two finger mocha shade. It has a wonderfully soft texture, and as it fades away, leaves behind plenty of lacing on the glass.

S: I don’t really pick up a ton of hops...at first. There’s a pleasant wave of brown sugar, nuts, and chocolate at first. Hops build up as it unravels in the glass, revealing both piny and herbal qualities. Maybe even a touch of mint. I must say, the hops are VERY well integrated within the maltier aspects of the aroma.

T: Aye...this is a bit of a letdown next to the nose. Subdued hops open this up - providing notes of grapefruit, mint, and pine - and roll all the way to the back end, being propped up by caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and faint chocolate. This malt backbone builds up on the finish, slowly but gradually. My problem here is that it seems like a cross between a boring IPA and a boring brown ale - it hybridizes the two styles well enough, but comes off blandly. When people rag on ’balanced’ brews, this is exactly what they’d rag on. Actually, come to think of it, since it’s too sweet, that would make it imbalanced...

M: It finishes rather sweet, and unfortunately, the hops don’t really dry it out as much as I’d like. Even worse, it lacks the creaminess I like out of most sweetish brews. For that reason, it’s hard to drink. On the plus side, there’s no remote hint of harshness in the feel.

O: It’s not a bad beer. Nor is it interesting, complex, or subtly executed. Basically this is just another average brown ale, only with a hint of hops. I say it’s well worth a try for those who like this style, but I won’t be back for this one.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby-brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of heavy liquorice, brown sugar, caramel, roasted malts and a hint of dark chocolate. flavour is mostly the same, grainy roasted malts, chocolate and bread crusts, slightly acrid, with a hint of alcohol and paint thinner in the light-bitter finish. medium to heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

Good one. Aromas of roasted malts with a hops floral essence in the background. Pours a chocolate brown with an off-white head. Palate has average weight and is a little creamy. Average carbonation. Good blend of flavors and falls in line with the description of a brown ale with an IPA twist. Bitterness is just enough to not distract and leave it as a roasted and malty brown ale.
